poem:
Title: "Symphony of History"

Ulster Hall, keeper of songs and stories,
once danced with Dickens, fueled Paisley's glory,
From dance floor to fight, War's hereditary,
echoes of Zeppelin's ascent, still carry.
Now symphonies resonate, a fresh score,
in melodies spun since '09, perhaps more,
And still, in quiet corners, silence roars,
the Ulster Orchestra's artful encore.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The week in classical: Riot Symphony; L’Olimpiade; LSO/Tilson Thomas review – humanity and hope From wartime dance hall to boxing arena to venue for political rallies, Belfast’s Ulster Hall has a grand and stormy history, dating back to 1862. Charles Dickens performed there; the Protestant loyalist Ian Paisley gave firebrand speeches; Led Zeppelin first performed Stairway to Heaven. Since 2009 it has been home to the Ulster Orchestra, Northern Ireland’s only professional symphony orchestra, which". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: The week in classical: Riot Symphony; L’Olimpiade; LSO/Tilson Thomas review – humanity and hope From wartime dance hall to boxing arena to venue for political rallies, Belfast’s Ulster Hall has a grand and stormy history, dating back to 1862.
